advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERTISEMENT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"TO8D, the smart present"<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Yoann Riou for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>"A step toward the future" <br><br> Hmmmm.....</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Christian Hart for this scan</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD #1 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The HHC advertising campain was not really attractive: black & white, lots of small characters texts, small pictures...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NOT REALLY AN IMSAI!</strong></font><br><blockquote>In october 1979, the IMSAI company went bankrupt. The IMSAI brand name and the spare parts stock were sold to the <b>Fischer-Freitas</b> Company. <br><br> This 1982 advert shows a Z80 CP/M based computer Fisher-Freitas tried to sell with the IMSAI name, without success.<br><br> Fisher-Freitas is still selling original parts for the 8080 model! and continue maintaining a nice 8080 history web site (see the Web links section).</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (FEB. 1980) </strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to David Wilson for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1977) #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert (May 1977) introduced the <b>System 16</b>, same as assembled System 7 with 16 Kb of RAM. ($1995)</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href=§http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage§>Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SPANISH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert says:<br><br> <font color ="#666666">The Altos ACS8000-6 series. It's a barrier breaker in every sense. Our entry level, single-user, hard-disk system with floppy backup is priced under $10,000...<br> ... With MP/M at the helm, your Altos system can support up to four simulteneous users with 48 KB RAM each plus 58 MB of Winchester storage and 4 MB of floppy backup. And that adds up to the first microcomputer to give you the power and performance of a minicomputer.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ONTEL ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Simplify your everyday life"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>found on the system box</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> IN THE KITCHEN...</strong></font><br><blockquote>A TO-7 in the kitchen? For sure it makes smile the woman!</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSERT - VERSO</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JANUARY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"At 68 years old, taunt Rose discovered that she was an exceptionally gifted child"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www1.cts.ne.jp/~sato/hp/">Sato's Homepage</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT FROM NEW ZEALAND</strong></font><br><blockquote>In November 1976, the assembled basic version cost A$931, the unassembled version cost A$599.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zealand</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (MAY 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>for the Commodore PET 3001</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PRINTERS ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US BROCHURE (VERSO)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Chris Collman for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT OCT 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Apple hardware advertisement.<br> From Personal Computing, October 1983 issue<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

computer.coprocessor: GTIA (video output, sprites), POKEY (sound, I/O), ANTIC (video, display lists), FREDDY (Memory Manager), PIA
computer.description:
The Atari 1400 XL has the same characteristics as the Atari 800/600 XL machines exept for some new features: a new custom chip called "FREDDY" which replaces the old discrete semiconductors & TTL chips of the 600/800 XL to manage the memory. It has a speech synthesizer chip (Votrax SC-01) and a built-in modem (Bell 103 compatible, 300 baud).
Thus it was conceived as an enhanced version of the Atari 600XL and 800XL computers and was to be software and hardware compatible with all the 8-bit Atari family systems.
It seems that this computer was never marketed... All existing models are thus considered as prototypes.
This system was also called by Atari A1201, Atari 1200 XLD and Atari 1200 XLT.
Another model was announced at the same time : the Atari 1450 XLD.

emulator.name: The Atari 800 Emulator for the Mac

emulator.description: Unix based emulator of the Atari eight bit computers, namely the Atari 400 and 800, the Atari 400XL, 800XL and 130XE, and the Atari 5200 game console
emulator.name: Atari++

emulator.description: Atari800 is an Atari 800, 800XL, 130XE and 5200 emulator for Unix, Amiga, MS-DOS, Atari TT/Falcon, SDL and WinCE
emulator.name: Atari800

item.description: Indus GT|||5''/14 disk-drive|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> INDUS GT</strong></font><br><strong>> 5''/14 disk-drive</strong><br><blockquote>The Indus GT Double Density Drive is considered by many the best floppy drive available for the 8-bit Atari's with its digital readouts and smoke plexi cover.</blockquote>

Astra 2001 FD unit|||Dual 5.25|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> ASTRA 2001 FD UNIT</strong></font><br><strong>> Dual 5.25</strong><br><blockquote>Dual 5.25" FDD unit using single side, single or double density floppy drives </blockquote>

Percom disc drive|||Advert|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> PERCOM DISC DRIVE</strong></font><br><strong>> Advert</strong><br><blockquote>March 1983 Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The Percom Data AT-88 offers 88 Kbytes (formatted) in single-density, with plug-in ease of attachment to your Atari. The AT-88 has integral power supply, "no-patch" to Atari DOS and critical constant speed regulation.<br> Take advantage of this low introductory price of $488... </font> </blockquote>

Corvus Systems hard-drive|||10Mb hard-drive|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> CORVUS SYSTEMS HARD-DRIVE</strong></font><br><strong>> 10Mb hard-drive</strong><br><blockquote>This is a 10Mb hard-drive. With up to 8 multiplexers with 8 ports each it's possible to connect up to 64 Atari 800's up to a single 10 or even 20 megabyte Atari system. Still in use Today at the Fordham Prepatory School in the Bronx, NY is a 64 Atari 800 computer network hooked up to a single Corvus Hard drive system ! <br><br> The Corvus hard disk system also sported a unique and innovative back-up system called "The Corvus Mirror" which was a VCR interface system that allowed you to plug a standard Video Cassette Recorder (VCR) up to the Corvus Hard Drive System to save back-ups of the hard disk onto actual Video Tapes!!!</blockquote>

Touch Tablet||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> TOUCH TABLET</strong></font><br><blockquote>The touch tablet was the best tool for drawing and painting. It shipped with the AtariArtist cartridge.</blockquote>

computer.name: 1400 XL
computer.ports: RGB, cartridge, Expansion port, Tape, RS232, Joystick
computer.rom: 16 KB (the Basic is on a cartridge)

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> LEFT SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>From left to right: <br><br> - On/Off switch<br> - Cartridge slot<br> - 2 x controller connectors</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR</strong></font><br><blockquote>From left to right: <br><br> - RF video output<br> - video channel 2/3 selection switch<br> - RGB monitor video output<br> - built-in modem sockets<br> - Parallel bus interface<br> - Serial I/O connector<br> - Power connector (from external PSU) </blockquote>

computer.text: five text modes, max: 40 x 24, min: 20 x 12
